content.rendered:
Some unusual selections this week with work from Barcelona, Glasgow, and Barcelona again.

IV Centenary of the death of Cervantes by Mucho

To commemorate the 4th centenary of the death of Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra — he of Don Quixote-writing fame — the Spanish government has established a national committee under a royal decree that will oversee the commemoration of the author. As soon as I saw the logo designed by the Barcelona office of Mucho I understood what it was, not because I am that smart but because the image of Cervantes wearing his neck ruff is so iconic. The “C” monogram is beautifully done and a perfect trigger for the sixteenth/seventeenth-century times of Cervantes when ruff was a hot thing. Not much in application but the logo alone is worth a spot on Friday Likes. See full project

Sword Maclean by Freytag Anderson

Sword Maclean is a luxury fashion and lifestyle brand in Scotland “reviving authentic Hebridean craftsmanship”. Their first collection will consist of leather products, woven textiles, and woollen knits that is titled “Dark Beauty” — a perfect description for the logo designed by Glasgow, Scotland-based Freytag Anderson. The blackletter-ish wordmark is beautiful and enigmatic, it feels both sexy and dangerous with its exaggerated curves and drastic cuts. It’s rare to see a contemporary take on blackletter and this logo offers a new perspective on approach and form. Not much again in application but a lovely wordmark worth celebrating this Friday. See full project

Odder by Aplauso

Odder organizes networking events for young people — specifically “odd people in a pessimistic world” and “exceptional people in a lost generation” — to get together and be odd together in Barcelona. Local firm Aplauso created a matching odd identity that plays off of the word “odd” as the basis and “er” as a kind of nth-degree treatment. Typeset in a monospace font with a fluorescent green is on trend and not necessarily surprising but the additional visual and verbal executions of the core idea are interesting, like Staff or weareodder.com. The applications are still a little shy and bare but they do have a youthful vibe that should play well with the lost generation of a pessimistic world. See full project
